abstract: The paper assesses the role and potential of Cultural Virtual Reality (CVR) for the modelling of archaeological landscapes. As digital visualisations are spreading rapidly as a tool for research and as a medium of communication in landscape research and archaeology, benefits and limitations are discussed. Published case studies are reviewed and the question whether or to which extent computer game engines may assist in the modelling of past landscapes is evaluated. Therefore a virtual model of Laxton castle (England) is introduced, which was created using SEGA gaming software.
article_title: Visualisation in archaeology: An assessment of modelling archaeological landscapes using scientific and gaming software
publisher: Edinburgh University Press  22 George Square, Edinburgh EH8 9LF UK
journal_title: International Journal of Humanities and Arts Computing
